subject: Re: [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
msgSnippet: ... fails if called with an invalid value? Hi, The @pre tag is used for jtest, it does a couple things... Helps to constrain the generated input args and helps
messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., Ilja Preu√ü <ilja.preuss@w...> wrote:
> What exactly does the @pre tag do? Does it test that the method
fails if called with an invalid value?

Hi,

The @pre tag is used for jtest, it does a couple things... Helps to
constrain the generated input args and helps to check relationship
behavior between classes.

For example, if the method throws exception when Vector size is
greater than 10 (exception found by Jtest), the developer says,
vector size is handled by the caller and is never going to be beyond
a certain range (an implied precondition -- every method has implied
contracts)...the contract can be made explicit so that it may be
checked programmatically as in below:

/**
* @pre vector_arg.size () <= 10
*/

u can also do things like:

/**
* @pre callMyMethodToCheckStateIsOK () == true
*/

And that method can do things like check db connection and so forth.

Jtest will constrain it's input generation so it does not violate the
@pre condition. Contracts can also validate through class
relationships, for example:

If "class A" calls methods in "class B" and Jtest is testing "class
A", IT WILL TRY to generate input to A's methods which break B's
contracts, hence letting you know there is a possibilty that the
class relationship is not well defined...let me know if u need more
elaboration on this point.

Carson
ParaSoft Support

>
> > --- In junit@y..., "rxqch" <rxqch@y...> wrote:
> > > Hi, I work with parasoft tech support and the answer to the
> > question
> > > below is yes. One can use an @pre tag in javadoc to find such
> > > problems.
> > >
> > > Carson
